message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical exam findings depict café-au-lait macules and axillary freckling, which are characteristic of neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). Iris hamartomas are also a common finding in NF1, while the other options are more associated with other genetic conditions such as tuberous sclerosis (ash-leaf spots), Fragile X syndrome (family history of seizures and mental retardation), and Klippel-Feil syndrome (white tuft of scalp hair since birth).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical exam findings suggest neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), which is associated with iris hamartomas. The other options are associated with other conditions: ash-leaf spots with tuberous sclerosis, family history of seizures and mental retardation with genetic disorders such as Down syndrome, and white tuft of scalp hair since birth with aplasia cutis congenita.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical examination findings suggest the patient has tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC). Among the options, only iris hamartomas (also known as epiretinal membranes or astrocytic hamartomas) are associated with TSC. Ash-leaf spots are also associated with TSC, but they are not depicted in the figures. A family history of seizures and mental retardation suggests a genetic condition such as Fragile X syndrome or Down syndrome, which are not related to TSC. A white tuft of scalp hair since birth suggests a neural tube defect or a form of ectodermal dysplasia, which are also not related to TSC.

We refer to the provided figures and relevant medical resources for help. The figures show cafe-au-lait spots and axillary freckling, which are characteristic findings of neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). Among the options, iris hamartomas are another common finding in NF1. Ash-leaf spots are associated with tuberous sclerosis, a different genetic disorder. A family history of seizures and mental retardation is associated with neurofibromatosis type 2. A white tuft of scalp hair since birth is associated with aplasia cutis congenita.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Figures A and B show facial angiofibromas and ungual fibromas, which are characteristic of tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC). Among the options, only iris hamartomas (also known as "phakomas") are another common feature of TSC. Ash-leaf spots are also a feature of TSC, but they are not depicted in the figures. Family history of seizures and mental retardation is not specific to TSC, and a white tuft of scalp hair since birth is a feature of aplasia cutis congenita, not TSC.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The findings depicted in Figures A and B suggest that the patient has a condition called tuberous sclerosis complex. Among the options, only iris hamartomas are a common finding in this condition. Ash-leaf spots are also seen in tuberous sclerosis complex, but they are not depicted in the figures. Family history of seizures and mental retardation may indicate other conditions, such as Down syndrome or Fragile X syndrome. A white tuft of scalp hair since birth may indicate a neural tube defect or congenital malformation of the scalp, but it is not typically associated with tuberous sclerosis complex.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical exam findings in figures A and B suggest the patient has tuberous sclerosis. Among the options, iris hamartomas are a common finding in patients with tuberous sclerosis, but the other options are associated with different conditions. Ash-leaf spots are seen in patients with Tuberous sclerosis and Vitiligo, a hereditary condition; a family history of seizures and mental retardation suggests neurodevelopmental disorders such as Fragile X Syndrome; a white tuft of scalp hair since birth suggests a congenital disorder called congenital atrichia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The findings in Figures A and B suggest neurofibromatosis type 1, which is associated with iris hamartomas. Ash-leaf spots are seen in tuberous sclerosis, a different condition. Seizures and mental retardation are seen in neurofibromatosis type 2, a different condition. A white tuft of scalp hair since birth is seen in aplasia cutis congenita, a different condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical exam findings in Figures A and B suggest the patient has tuberous sclerosis. Among the options, only iris hamartomas are associated with tuberous sclerosis. Ash-leaf spots are also associated with tuberous sclerosis, but they are not depicted in the figures provided.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Figures A and B show the presence of multiple café-au-lait macules, which are a common finding in neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). Among the options, only iris hamartomas (also known as Lisch nodules) are a characteristic feature of NF1. Ash-leaf spots are seen in tuberous sclerosis, a different genetic disorder. A family history of seizures and mental retardation is suggestive of a genetic disorder like neurofibromatosis type 2 or tuberous sclerosis, but not specifically NF1. A white tuft of scalp hair since birth is seen in congenital dermal melanocytosis (Mongolian spot), which is a benign pigmented lesion and not associated with NF1.
